abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            Tatev's new road in Armenia, which lead to economic
            revival. The road to Tatev monastery, a 9th century
            monastery, is an architectural masterpiece, a landmark, and
            a tourist attraction which winds through a spectacular gorge
            with rocky slopes and lush forests. It once connected
            several villages, but became so dilapidated that it was
            known not as the most beautiful pass in Armenia, but as the
            most dangerous one. The government, with World Bank support,
            rebuilt new road to Tatev, which lures tourists from Armenia
            and beyond once again, and benefits these isolated
            communities. One of the main goals of the Tatev revival
            project, which upgraded the road and other infrastructure
            here, was to connect the area's heritage with
            today's development. As a result, the Wings of Tatev,
            the longest aerial tramway in the world, spanning the
            Vorotan River Gorge, was built and is already a major
            attraction for tourists. The roads linking villages to
            highways are often called lifeline roads in Armenia, as they
            are vital for communities, located dozens of kilometers away
            from urban centers. The World Bank-supported project has
            ended geographic and economic isolation of rural
            communities. It has fixed almost 300 kilometers of roads in
            over 80 communities in Armenia, and has created thousands of
            short-term jobs.
